Is this to show your growing distaste for the question,

10.23.17  7:22 pm   So my parents aren't musicians but my mom tells me she used to obsessively play classical music a bunch while she was pregnant with me. I didn't touch a keyboard until I was 6 or 7. Anyway, now I'm 20 and I've been doing music stuff for like 10+ years with few lessons(or direction) but I know middle "C" indefinitely. And because I know "C" i can figure out every other note too(maybe I'm not explaining this right) my point is i can figure out any notes to a thing as long as I think from "C" first. I explained this to my teacher and he was like "that's perfect pitch" but I always thought perfect pitch was effortless.

     right. you have a very effective and wily workaround, which i have as well

      Honestly it doesn't matter much to me cuz I got to where I was thinking I'm relative pitch so even if I don't have perfect pitch It's not like it's impossible to be good with relative.

     right. to be a musician, relative pitch is 100% required. perfect pitch (otherwise known as "absolute pitch") really doesn't have anything to do with music and is not required at all to be a good musician, and is really not even a reliable indicator of good musicianship

      I was just wondering I you ever heard of this kind of thing. Take care. -bro-bro

     but here's the ironic thing: there are many many people who frolic all over the place telling people they have perfect pitch, but whenever you test them, they're not even close. my point is, if you have the skill that you have (springboarding off a strong memory of C) then not only can you get the job done, but you can probably do it better than most people who actually claim to have it. so i say you might as well just say you have it. to increase your strength, familiarize yourself with where a low C is in your vocal register, (you can usually hum it quietly, should be a casual and easy note for a male, if you are a male) and just practice trying to find that note while other songs are playing. also familiarize yourself with the key of every song you've ever heard, and always learn what key songs are in. this will help you even more. perfect pitch (absolute pitch), or the sneaky workaround you have, is not at all required to be a wonderful and great musician, BUT it will provide you with an extra edge in professional situations

10.23.17  7:14 pm   remember your opinion on 404 pages? "nah. fuck it. 404 pages tell me "we took more designing this than trying to fix the fucking problem"" remember you said that? so i think is really ironic to have one right know. did you change your opinion on 404 pages? i think is useless.

     as you can see, i put no effort into mine. so i think that is congruent with my attitudes about 404 pages. i said this just a couple days ago and i will say it again, it is ironic to me that everyone always wondered why i never had one, and now that i have one people are wondering why i have one. oh well i guess it just goes to show you

10.23.17  5:59 pm   You have mentioned that it works best to write a song completely before you record it. This sounds like a great method for me because it's hard to finish songs once I get them started. However, I can't really play instruments well so recording (or sequencing it depending on the style) the song IS writing it. Any advice?

     i'm not sure what you mean. in one way it sounds like you are saying you can't record songs, only write them. but at the same time it sounds like you are saying you can't write songs, only record them. writing just means making a plan for what you are going to record. not usually exactly every detail, but you will know what it's going to say and generally what's going to happen. then when you get to actually making the thing, then you can figure out how to use those tools to best represent how you planned for the song to go

10.23.17  5:29 pm   do you stop listening to songs before they've finished?

     yes

     do you do it often?

     yes, most of the time

10.23.17  5:29 pm   What is the best way tp not fuck up exams 

     get the right answers, i suppose

10.23.17  5:10 pm   Complete the joke: A priest and a rabbi walked into a bar.....

     nevermind you had to be there

10.23.17  4:17 pm   Do you ever just feel the need to AAAAAAAAAAAAAAAHHHHHHHHHHHH

     yes

10.23.17  4:14 pm   if your songs page has all of these snippits of songs from your vine why isn't "lets go to africa and find love in the jungle" on it

     that's a good qustion. drawing the line for what gets included on the songs page is an ambiguous and imperfect endeavor. i have changed my mind several times and it will never be quite right. it's this kind of ambiguity that this entire site was built in the face of. the entire reason this site exists is because i was able to learn to live with that sort of ambiguity

     whatever your own name is

10.23.17  3:14 pm   Do you do things besides provide content? Some people would say that only providing content isn't considered having a life (being an interesting person) What is your opinion on having a life, aside from the literality (being alive)? Unless the literality (carbon based, programmed to be artificially intelligent, etc.) is your opinion, in which case; ok. You probably get this often, thanks for answering.

     "do you have a life" is usually said to try to make someone feel bad about their life. i'm not sure if that answers your question

10.23.17  2:31 pm   I feel like I'm stuck on a plateau in terms of creativity/skill and don't know how to keep climbing up. I know the solution is not think about how 'good' my stuff is and just to keep writing, which I am doing.. but I'm  getting frustrated and having a hard time being satisfied with the stuff I make. When I was first learning I could write something super simple using just open chords or something, and I'd fall in love with it. Be so proud of it and show off my new song to all my friends.. The funny thing is I like a lot of those first songs I wrote just as much, if not more, than the stuff I'm doing now. And I think a lot of it has to do with the mindset I had then. I remember first learning how to play a C7 chord and thinking 'Oh man, this is so cool!!' Have you ever felt like you reached the top of a plateau?

     no

      How did you turn your plateau back into a mountain? 

     i think you are up against a simple nostalgia problem. nostalgia gets us again and again, and it goes in waves. soon you will realize that anything you've ever done is no more 'special' than any new thing you can now do. and the things you did then were once things you had never done, where perhaps back then you were emotionally attached to some other previous thing. you will eventually get out of this by just putting on your hustling cap and doing whatever you can, do many many many things, just jump in and start going crazy. the bad news is you will probably have nostalgic feelings later for this, looking back. and then you just repeat the cycle
